58ca9f8575eb5.Output_template:
{"systemID":"59a4f21090a7f","systemName":"Firmstep Solutions Read","lookup_validation":"0","results_page_columns_db":"","secure_fields_db_database":"","escapeTokens":"yes","query":"select * From
(select
	1 as IDZZ,
	1 as existSelected,
	1 as existingCustomer,
	{Organisation_Name} as Organisation_Name_out,
	{Title} as Title_out,
	{First_Name} as First_Name_out,
	{Surname} as Surname_out,
	{flat} as flat_out,
	{house} as house_out,
	{street} as street_out,
	{town} as town_out, 
	if({country} IS NOT NULL and {country} != '' and {country} != 'United Kingdom','',{postcode}) as postcode_out5,
	if({country} IS NOT NULL and {country} != '' and {country} != 'United Kingdom',{postcode},'') as zIPPostcode,
	{country} as country_out,
	{country_id} as sel_country,
	{uprn} as uprn_out,
	{lng} as lng_out,
	{lat} as lat_out,
	{Date_of_Birth} as Date_of_Birth_out,
	{Email_Address} as Email_Address_out,
	{Mobile_Number} as Mobile_Number_out,
	{Phone_Number} as Phone_Number_out,
	'ProAi' as haveRun
union select
	2 as IDZZ,
	'' as existSelected,
	'' as existingCustomer,
	{Organisation_Name} as Organisation_Name_out,
	{Title} as Title_out,
	{First_Name} as First_Name_out,
	{Surname} as Surname_out,
	'' as flat_out,
	'' as house_out,
	'' as street_out,
	'' as town_out, 
	'' as postcode_out5,
	'' as zIPPostcode,
	'' as country_out,
	'' as sel_country,
	'' as uprn_out,
	'' as lng_out,
	'' as lat_out,
	{Date_of_Birth} as Date_of_Birth_out,
	{Email_Address} as Email_Address_out,
	{Mobile_Number} as Mobile_Number_out,
	{Phone_Number} as Phone_Number_out,
	'ProAe' as haveRun) Combine
Where
	IDZZ = (select if({subParm} like '%dA%' 
			and {subParm} not like '%oNA%'
			and {postcode} is not null ,1,2) as test)"}

{"systemID":"59a4f21090a7f","systemName":"Firmstep Solutions Read","lookup_validation":"0","results_page_columns_db":"","secure_fields_db_database":"","escapeTokens":"yes","query":"select
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), {flat}, '') as flat_out,
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), {house}, '') as house_out,
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), {street}, '') as street_out,
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), {town}, '') as town_out, 
	IF(({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%')
		and ({country} IS NULL or {country} = '' or {country} = 'United Kingdom')), {postcode}, '') as postcode_out5,
	IF(({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%')
		and ({country} IS NOT NULL and {country} != '' and {country} != 'United Kingdom')), {postcode}, '') as zIPPostcode,
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), {country}, '') as country_out,
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), {uprn}, '') as uprn_out,
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), {lng}, '') as lng_out,
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), {lat}, '') as lat_out,
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), 1, '') as existSelected,
 IF({existingCustomer} = 1 or ({subParam} like '%dA%' and {haveRun} like '%Ae%'), 1, '') as existingCustomer,
 'ProcAi' as haveRun"}

58efbd46c0cbd.Output_template: {"systemID":"59a4f21090a7f","systemName":"Firmstep Solutions Read","query":"select a.*, if(b.p1 + b.p2 + b.p3 - b.p4 > 2,'Entered','') as uprn_selected, if(b.p1 + b.p2 + b.p3 - b.p4 > 2,'',1) as Address_Found, if(b.p1 + b.p2 + b.p3 - b.p4 > 2,'',concat(if(b.p1 + b.p2 + b.p3 < 3,'The address must contain a flat or house number, road and postcode. ',''),if(b.p4 = 1,' The postcode must contain a space, for e.g. "PO1 2AL"',''))) as confMsg, '' as confirmAddress, b.* from (select 123 as id, {flat_out1} as flat_out, {house_out1} as house_out, {street_out1} as street_out, {town_out1} as town_out, {postcode_out51} as postcode_out5, {zIPPostcode1} as zIPPostcode, {country_out1} as country_out, {sel_country} as country_id_out, '' as uprn_out, '' as lng_out, '' as lat_out, '' as existSelected, '' as existingCustomer) as a RIGHT JOIN (select if(c.p1 + c.p2 + c.p3 - c.p4 > 2,'123','321') as id, c.* from (select if({flat_out1} != '' or {house_out1} != '',1,if({subParam} like '%mAd%',0,1)) as p1, if({street_out1} != '',1,if({subParam} like '%mAd%',0,1)) as p2, if({postcode_out51} != '' or {zIPPostcode1} != '',1,if({subParam} like '%mAd%' or {subParam} like '%mPo%',0,1)) as p3, if({postcode_out51} REGEXP '(((^[BEGLMNSbeglmns][1-9][0-9]?)|(^[Ww][2-9])|(^([Aa][BLbl]|[Bb][ABDHLNRSTabnhlnrst]|[Cc][ABFHMORTVWabfhmortvw]|[Dd][ADEGHLNTYadeghlnty]|[Ee][HNXhnx]|[Ff][KYky]|[Gg][LUYluy]|[Hh][ADGPRSUXadgprsux]|[Ii][GMPVgmpv]|[JEje]|[Kk][ATWYatwy]|[Ll][ADELNSUadelnsu]|[Mm][EKLekl]|[Nn][EGNPRWegnprw]|O[LXlx]|[Pp][AEHLORaehlor]|[Rr][GHMghm]|[Ss][AEGKL-Paegkl-pRSTWYrstwy]|[Tt][ADFNQRSWadfnqrsw]|[Uu][Bb]|[Ww][ADFNRSVadfnrsv]|YO|ZE|yo|ze)[0-9][0-9]?)|(^[Ww]1[A-Ha-hJKSTUWjkstuw0-9])|(((^[Ww][Cc][1-2])|(^[Ee][Cc][1-4])|(^[Ss][Ww]1))[ABEHMNPRVWXYabehmnprvwxy]))[_ ]([0-9][ABD-Habd-hJLNP-Ujlnp-uW-Zw-z]{2}))$|(^[Gg][Ii][Rr][_ ]0[Aa]{2})$',0,if({postcode_out51} != '',1,0)) as p4) as c) as b ON a.id = b.id","results_page_columns_db":"","secure_fields_db_database":"","escapeTokens":"yes"}

props.label: html 1
props.content: Complete this form to request a new social media account. Please read our 'social media approach and guidelines' document.

props.label: html 1
props.content:
Social media guide for staff

How we use and manage social media at Portsmouth City Council

  1. Introduction

    2. This document sets out the approach taken to managing social media by marketing and communications and the digital customer experience team. It also provides guidance for staff, within the service and across the council, on the most appropriate ways to use and manage social media.

    This is a working document and intended as a guidance rather than strict instruction because the constantly evolving nature of social media means any specifics could be outdated very quickly.

  2. Managing social media

    Social media is constantly changing. Social media platforms are owned by private companies. They are free to use, which is hugely positive for the council when budgets are limited, but the way the platforms are set-up and managed changes frequently, which means we have to change with them. Hence our approach to social media needs to be flexible.

    Public use of social media is also a constantly evolving landscape, which means our approach to using social media channels needs to be flexible too, with an emphasis on current research (and on-going evaluation of communications and marketing activity) to determine the best social media tools to use to reach target audiences.

    The role of the digital customer experience team is to oversee the use of corporate social media channels, managing the toolsets and providing oversight (in line with capacity) to ensure there is consistency of approach across all digital channels.

    The role of the marketing and communications team is to communicate effectively with the councils target audiences to achieve specific marketing and communications objectives. Social media is used to support marketing and communications activity where appropriate to objectives/audiences, using free (organic) and paid for advertising (sponsored) content.

    Customer enquiries via social media are handled by the digital customer assistants, with advice and support from marketing and communications and the city helpdesk customer contact centre as needed.

    Reflecting the changing landscape, this document will be reviewed and updated every 12 months.

    1. Corporate accounts

      2. The council's primary social media channels (known as the corporate accounts) are managed by the newly established digital customer experience team (created as part of a review in 2017), providing strategic direction, oversight of all accounts and best practice guidance on use, content and analytics, ensuring a consistent approach across all channels that supports the council's brand and digital customer service.

      The official corporate accounts are: Portsmouth City Council facebook, Portsmouth City Council Instagram, Portsmouth City Council Twitter (@portsmouthtoday), Portsmouth City Council Vimeo, Portsmouth City Council YouTube, and Portsmouth City Council Flickr.

      In addition, the marketing and communications team are responsible for a number of accounts for specific marketing campaigns or projects. These are facebook pages for Portsmouth Lottery, Southsea Coastal Scheme, Health and Care Portsmouth, Housetalk, Term Times and Beware of Lurking Trolls; a twitter account for Southsea Coastal Scheme @southseacs; and an Instagram account for Southsea Coastal Scheme.

      As with other digital channels, the team works closely with:

      • marketing and communications to ensure the primary social media accounts are effective in support marketing and communications objectives
      • city help desk to ensure customer needs are being met

      The marketing and communications team have access to the corporate accounts to create and upload content as part of marketing and communications campaigns and activity. The marketing and communications team can also provide best practice guidance on use, content and analytics.

      Where platform restrictions allow, we aim to ensure social media channels are managed through master account logins that relevant officers can access. This creates a central point where everything is recorded and prevents any difficulties with having to update multiple accounts with any changes. However, this approach varies slightly from platform to platform depending on how much they allow accounts/pages to be managed.

      To keep the accounts secure, passwords are stored in a folder with restricted access and are changed each month and whenever a member of staff leaves the team.

      Service accounts are covered in section 2.3 below.

    2. Platforms

      3. The digital customer experience and marketing and communications teams use the following social media platforms:

      Facebook

      Facebook is the team's primary social media channel, using the @portsmouthcitycouncil page along with a number of campaign specific pages (see appendix B). The page currently has almost 12,000 likes, and is used to post organic content and paid for advertising. The platform has comprehensive analytics, which are used to extract monthly paid for and organic reach, which contribute to our performance indicators.

      Facebook is also used as a customer service channel, with any genuine customer enquiries on our page, in comments under posts and via direct messages being responded to in accordance with the guidelines at appendix A.

      Access to Facebook is managed through a master account, and via Hootsuite.

      Twitter

      The team uses @portsmouthtoday on Twitter and has 10.3K followers. The channel is used to post organic content, and the organic reach is captured and contributes to our performance indicators. As with Facebook, Twitter is also used as a customer service channel, with genuine customer enquiries posted at us or via direct messages being responded to in accordance with the guidelines at appendix A.

      Access to Twitter is managed through a master account, and via Hootsuite.

      Instagram

      The council's Instagram account is a new (2017) addition to the social media platforms and currently has 522 followers, using @portsmouthcitycouncil.

      As Instagram is a picture sharing site, our use is limited to campaigns/events for which we have images, which limits its usefulness. Access to Instagram is managed through the main Instagram account.

      YouTube and Vimeo (video content)

      Video content is mainly hosted on Vimeo (vimeo.com/portsmouthcitycouncil), which enables video to be embedded in the council's website and linked from other social media platforms. Access to Vimeo is managed through the main Vimeo account.

      The council also has a YouTube account, which is occasionally used to host video content.

      Access is via the main You Tube account.

      Flickr

      Flickr is an image-sharing site, which has been used in the past to manage submitted pictures as part of competitions and other image sharing initiatives.

      Flickr belongs to Yahoo, and so access is via a yahoo.com email address, which has been set-up and is managed by the graphic design team (part of marketing and communications).

      https://www.flickr.com/photos/portsmouthcitycouncil

      Linked-in

      There is a Portsmouth City Council page on Linked-in but this is not used by marketing and communications currently.

      Linked-in company pages can only be accessed by Linked-in members, who have been given admin rights. Admin rights can be assigned by any page administrator. The page has a number of administrators, including the assistant director of community and communications, but is predominantly used by HR for recruitment purposes and the business engagement team.

      https://www.linkedin.com/company/portsmouth-city-council

  3. Service specific accounts
    1. Introduction

      2. The digital customer experience team and marketing and communications team do not have capacity to manage social media accounts for every council service.

      An approach has been put in place for Facebook (see below) which ensures the central team can access pages should urgent changes/moderation be required. Facebook pages that are set up following the process for new service accounts are created using this approach.

      As other social media channels operate in different ways, the same approach is not possible for service twitter, Instagram and other social media accounts. Therefore there is no process through which the central team can access accounts if urgent changes/moderation is required.

      There are also a number of accounts that have been historically established by services over which the marketing and communications and digital customer experience teams currently have no oversight.

    2. Process for creating new service accounts

      3. The published process for requesting a new social media presence is available on the intranet.https://www.portsmouth.gov.uk/intranet/about-us/communications/website-intranet-and-social-media

      Where a service feels social media could help achieve its objectives they are advised to contact the marketing and communications team, via their account manager, to discuss the following:

      • the objective or purpose of their proposed social media account
      • whether social media is appropriate for that objective/audience
      • whether a new social media channel is required or if one already exists that can be used

    3. availability of sufficient resources to support a new social media channel - who will maintain the page with regular updates, moderation, respond to messages from the public etc

      If the marketing and communications team agree a new social media presence is appropriate, the service will need to ensure the request is signed-off by a third tier manager and will need to make a commitment to manage their new social media channel in line with the approach and guidelines set out in this document.

      The digital customer experience team will set up the social media account, including assisting with appropriate collateral for profile pictures to ensure the council's brand is represented and, along with the marketing and communications team, will work with the service to ensure the account runs smoothly in its early stages. New Facebook pages will be linked to the main corporate account to ensure the central teams can access pages/feeds if urgent moderation is required.

    4. Personal social media accounts

      5. Staff should not, under any circumstances, use their personal social media accounts for work purposes.

      Services that need individual Facebook profiles to fulfil editor roles for Facebook pages should set up specific individual Facebook profiles for this purpose. Instructions on how to do this will be provided to services if a new service account is agreed.

    5. Day-to-day management of service accounts

      6. Once the channel is up and running, the service takes day-to-day responsibility for managing and maintaining their account, following the guidance in later sections on proactive messages (section 4) and reactive messages (section 5).

      The digital customer team will maintain limited oversight of the Facebook pages that are linked to the corporate account, as part of its remit to ensure quality and consistency across digital customer channels. The digital customer team will check service Facebook pages that are connected to the main account every two months, and contact the service contacts if they notice any obvious issues.

      If there is no activity on a Facebook page and no likelihood of activity soon, the page will be deemed dormant and will be unpublished (in consultation with the service contact) - this means it is not publicly visible but is retained in case the channel or any of its content is needed in the future.

    6. Access and security

      7. In order to ensure staff from outside marketing and communications/digital customer only have access to the service accounts they need, Facebook accounts for services are set-up by the digital customer team using a master account. Individual accounts nominated by the service are then given appropriate permissions to use the channel. This enables services to access their own accounts, without having access to the corporate accounts, and means the marketing and communications/digital customer teams can access the page should there be a situation, such as an emergency, when a message needs to be put out or inappropriate content deleted but officers from the service are unavailable.

      This approach supports oversight of the content being produced, and any customer interactions, by ensuring the marketing and communications/digital customer teams can access service accounts from one master account if necessary - although it should be noted that services are responsible for their own accounts as the central team does not have capacity to oversee multiple channels.

      This approach is not possible with other social media channels so only applies to Facebook.

      Services are responsible for maintaining the security of their own accounts.

      Passwords should be stored securely in a central location. Passwords should be changed monthly as well as when a member of staff with access leaves the department or organisation.

  4. Legal considerations and other regulations

    1. Privacy and GDPR

      2. Pages should adhere to the council's privacy notice which can be found here https://www.portsmouth.gov.uk/ext/the-council/data-protection-privacy-notice, specifically the section 'people who contact us via social media'. The data protection privacy notice should be referred to in the 'about' section of the page.

      If a request for personal data is made via social media, for example for a competition entry, then specific reference should be made to the data protection privacy notice as above.

    2. Party political content
      3. The council is politically neutral. As with all communications, content that could be construed as party political should not be used on the council's social media presences. If you are linking to content on social media - from another organisation or individual - you should always follow the links to ensure you have not inadvertently promoted party political material. If you are in any doubt as to whether the content you are using could be considered to be party political, you should discuss with your manager or contact communications@portsmouthcc.gov.uk for advice.

    3. Purdah

      Purdah is the name given to the period in the run up to an election when the council must take additional care around publicity and promotion, to ensure it is not inadvertently using resources in ways that could be deemed likely to influence voters or promote a candidate, or in any way promote one political interest over another.

      The council's purdah guidance can be found on the intranet by searching 'purdah' and is updated in advance of each election. This guidance MUST be applied to social media.

      As the council has elections in three out of every four years, it is important to keep the purdah regulations in mind and look out for the internal communications reminders.

    4. Keeping it legal

      5. There are a number of legal considerations to keep in mind when using social media.

      The list below is designed to highlight some potential areas but is not exhaustive. If you think something you are considering posting could have legal implications, firstly consider why you want to post and whether posting is really necessary as seeking advice will mean officers from marketing and communications and legal services investing time in the issue. If posting is necessary, then contact communications@portsmouthcc.gov.uk in the first instance. The marketing and communications team will discuss with you, and seek legal advice if necessary.

      Libel: if you publish an untrue statement about someone they could take libel action. Don't publish information unless you are sure it is correct. If you are considering publishing something that could damage the reputation of an individual or organisation, contact communications@portsmouthcc.gov.uk for advice first.

      Copyright: publishing pictures or video without consent is likely to breach copyright. Check you have permission to use any images or video you are planning to post, and get consent in writing. Do not download images and video from the internet, unless the content explicitly says it is copyright free.

  5. Code of conduct and internet usage policy

    6. Staff using social media should do so in accordance with the council's code of conduct for employees, which forms part of the constitution and can be found on the main council website: https://www.portsmouth.gov.uk/ext/documents-external/cou-policies-constitution-part4c.pdf

    Social media should also be used in line with relevant IT policies, which can be found on Policy Hub (accessible via the intranet - search 'policy hub').

  6. Guidance on how to use social media
    1. Proactive content

      2. Messages

      Social media should only be used as part of a wider communications plan and content should be informed by the same key messages used for other channels, with tone adjusted for social media as per below guidance.

      Tone

      Messages should be written in a tone appropriate to the medium, with most social media geared towards a friendlier conversational tone compared to more traditional correspondence, principles to follow are:

      • keep language clear and simple
      • avoid council jargon or technical terms
      • be friendly but remain professional - you are still representing the council

      Be engaging

      Rich content such as pictures and video should be used where possible as these are more engaging and can generate a bigger reach for your messages.

      Frequency

      Social media channels should be fairly active, ideally there should be several new posts each week.

      Relevance

      Content should be relevant to the channel and the audience it builds - for example a message about a library event wouldn't be relevant to a channel for traffic information.

      Third-party content

      It is okay to share third-party content as long as it is appropriate and relevant to the channel/audience and we credit the originator where appropriate.

      If third party links are included, the site that is linked to should be checked to ensure it does not contain content that is not appropriate for us to share. This could be because it is offensive, or because it is linked to a political party or political campaign group.

      In many instances it is better to share content from a partner agency's channel than write our own message, particularly where the council has no real responsibility for the subject/issue. This approach shows the council as being helpful in sharing information for a partner organisations or one of our contractors, but can help maintain an appropriate distance so any customer enquiries go to the correct place. This is important, as it saves customers wasting time contacting the council about issues that are not our responsibility and saves us time responding to issues that don't belong to us.

      We should not promote political parties via social media either by expressing a particular political view or by sharing third party content belonging to a particular political party.

      Paid-for advertising

      As with all other advertising channels, paid-for advertising should only be used on social media as part of a wider marketing or communications plan for a service or project (that has been developed with the marketing and communications team).

  7. Reactive messages - responding to customers

    Appendix A 'Social customer service, guide for customer-facing staff' contains the standards and protocols the digital customer service team works to when dealing with customer enquiries on social media.

    Services managing their own social media channels must adhere to these standards.

props.label: html 2
props.content:
APPENDIX A

Social customer service: a guide for customer-facing staff

How to respond to a customer on social customer service channels

This guidance recognises that while we aim to respond to 100% of customer enquiries on social media, the nature of social media threads, comments and replies can make it difficult to locate every relevant post.

Principles

  • respond in channel wherever possible or publically explain why it is necessary to move them to a different channel
  • make sure responses are timely
    • make initial acknowledgement as soon as possible
    • aim for a target of initial acknowledgment within four working hours
  • if confidential/personal info needs to be exchanged, move enquiry to direct/private messages
  • remember, interactions are in the public domain
  • if an issue is sensitive, political or has potential to turn into a crisis, escalate to the duty media officer

Not responding: when to moderate

Remove the following:

  • posts that contain sexual imagery, or references
  • posts that contain swear words
  • posts that could be construed as bullying, racist, sexist, homophobic or abusive towards a particular person, religion, ethnicity, minority or community
  • SPAM advertising posts
  • posts that mention council staff by name, or make derogatory comments or accusations about individual officers or councillors
  • posts that breach the privacy of another individual by including their personal information or details

Before removing posts take a screenshot of them and send it to so there is a record of why the post was removed.

Responding: approach and tone

  • Listen - make sure you have fully understood the customer's question or issue
  • Empathise - make the customer feel you understand and validate their feelings - use phrases like 'it's completely understandable you feel that way'
  • Personalise responses - acknowledge the problem and apologise if appropriate
  • Resolve - seek to resolve the issue and let the customer know it has been handled

Responding: language

  • keep language clear and simple
  • avoid council jargon or technical terms
  • be friendly but remain professional - you are still representing the council

Responding: sift for genuine enquiries

Review incoming messages and comments/post either directly or using Hootsuite.

Channels should be checked for new messages/comments/posts every two hours

Identify and respond to any messages that contain:

  • customer asking a direct question
  • a customer expressing dissatisfaction
  • a customer with an urgent service need
  • issues with potential to escalate
  • general comments or suggestions

Responding: prioritise

Review messages that require action, and prioritise. Priority one messages should be dealt with as soon as they are seen, with all other messages actioned as soon as possible in priority order.

Priority one

  • potentially dangerous issues (For example, broken glass, needles, broken traffic signals)

ACTION

Where enough information provided by customer:

  • make urgent report to relevant department, such as TMC or Colas
  • request feedback when the issue is resolved, request timescale
  • respond to customer, let them know issue has been reported and timescale for fix
  • receive feedback when issue has been resolved
  • respond to customer to end enquiry

Where not enough information provided by customer

  • explain extra information required and direct to appropriate form on website or app, including explanation these routes provide quicker customer service
  • potentially contentious or high profile issues, likely to cause reputation damage

ACTION

  • make urgent report to communications via duty media officer
  • work with duty media officer to agree who will request information for response
  • respond to customer to let them know we are investigating
  • agree response with duty media officer
  • respond to customer to end enquiry
  • a customer with an urgent service need

ACTION

  • make urgent report to relevant department
  • Reply to message explaining we will private message to get contact info etc and/or offer direct contact details for the service
  • respond to customer to let them know where request has been raised to and who will be in contact

Priority two

  • customer asking a direct question

ACTION

  • pass question to relevant department
  • respond to customer to let them know we are investigating
  • receive response from department
  • post response for customer
  • a customer expressing dissatisfaction

ACTION

  • pass issue to relevant department
  • respond to the customer to let them know we are investigating
  • receive response from department
  • post response for customer
  • customer requesting a council service

ACTION

  • pass request to relevant department
  • Reply to message explaining we will private message to get contact info etc and/or offer direct contact details for the service
  • respond to customer letting them know where request has been raised to and who will be in contact
  • general comments or suggestions

ACTION

  • pass comment or suggestion to relevant department and request feedback
  • respond to customer thanking them for their comment/suggestion
  • IF feedback is received, follow-up with feedback response to customer
